I do not believe the deployment failure of Galileo was due to cold welding. I was told that it was due to the long term storage of the spacecraft (due to the Challenger accident) and the fact that they did not purge the antenna mechanical assemblies with gas to keep moisture from being absorbed by the lubricant that was on the mechanisms. I work for the company that makes that lubricant and part of the failure review board was the determination that NASA was not aware of the purge requirement for this lube in the long term storage.

We currently DO purge any mechanisms that contain our lube for this very reason.

Also - The spacecraft was not in space long enough for cold welding to occur after release from the shuttle before antenna deployment.

Cold welding is also a phenomenon in ball milling, especially in metal powder such as aluminum (Al). If you mill Al powder in a ball miller (under vacuum or protection gas), the particles first flatten and break in smaller pieces. However, when they break they create a new fresh powder surface which will stick together with other particles and create bigger particles than the original powder. To prevent this, we usually use a process control agent, such as stearic acid or other organic materials.

This also rarely happens with metal Gauge Blocks with very fine surface finish. When you "stick" them together by sliding their surfaces to each other, you simply press the air between the surfaces out by sliding, they might cold weld together if you leave them like that for several days. After that, breaking the weld messes up with the surfaces of those blocks eventually causing slight error in your measurements. So it was also a thing to avoid for something that is just being used as a ruler.

Dr Miller
“Cold welding” is actually commonplace on Earth. My background is metallurgy, I’ve worked in steel and aluminum sheet rolling mills. Some examples:
- When we roll a metal coil from ingot, new surface is created as it is elongated. In manufacture of clad products, two slabs are rolled together in a hot mill. As the oxide in between is broken during hot rolling, the two metal alloys adhere to one another due to the vacuum between the pieces. This same process has been shown to work with cold rolling as well. The University of Michigan has a lab scale unit for demonstration.
- During stamping of sheet metal, galling may occur when the oxide of the softer metal splits and comes into contact with the metal of the die in the absence of air. Air/oxygen is absent because of high pressure and the presence of lube. Metal sticking may be called adhesion, and small amounts of metal on the die increase the local pressure there during stamping of the next part, leading to more galling and buildup on the die.

In summary, metals bond to one another in a vacuum and you don’t need to go to space to observe it. This phenomenon is used intentionally in manufacturing, and using dissimilar metals does not necessarily decrease the likelihood of bonding. Metal-to-metal bonding can also be unwelcome, and requires die maintenance and intentional planning to control, such as the use of dry film lubes versus wet lubes.

Ah, I see. Although the metal being oxide free is a requirement of cold welding the real reasons that we don't see metals on Earth cold welding is that only soft metals are capable of cold welding and (outside a vacuum) you need to press very hard on metals to get them to cold weld (to the point that you are going to be generating quite a lot of heat and probably deforming the metal) in order to drive the atmosphere gasses out of the joint. There are a few exceptions like indium that will cold weld outside a vacuum but the weld isn't very impressive without a lot of force. Cold welding is also related to another process called galling. Galling is when two metals weld together due to the friction of them sliding against each other. You can get much better results when cold welding if you also slide the pieces together because this creates grooves that give much better contact. Because spacecraft are made on Earth the parts will generally never cold weld (even in a vacuum) because they are already oxidized before they go up. The only way to make most parts cold weld is to slide them against each other and scrape off the oxidation layer and (at the same time) form symmetrical cavities in the two pieces. Then they will cold weld\gall.

Here’s a thing. Guns in space. I mean a standard terrestrial firearm and not one optimised for space. So a fire arm has fine tolerances keeping moving metal parties very close. Now these parts are cleaned and I mean really cleaned but then they are oiled. So if you fire a gun in space your screwed after a few shots as you have very poor cooling as IR cooling is all you’ll have with no atmosphere and the gun will be blistering hot. The propellant burns in the chamber at a few thousand degrees and then that rumbles down the barrel as well. So any oil will be cooked off pretty quickly at suck high temperatures and no atmospheric pressure. The moving bolt if it’s semi automatic, fully automatic and just bolt action will eventually wear a clean spot and I think pretty quickly. And then bam cold weld.

Puts standard gun fights is space to bed without optimised weapons. Thank the goddess.

I think you're conflating two different physical phenomena here.  "Cold welding" happens easily here on planet Earth if the wrong materials are chosen for a sliding contact application.  Sounds to me this is what happened with the Gemini hatch with unlubricated titanium and aluminum in sliding contact.  In other words, it was a basic design screw up.  If you want to try this for yourself, run a stainless steel bolt in and out of a stainless steel nyloc nut with a power tool.  You very likely won't get past two or three cycles before the bolt and nut fuse together.

It is in wide use in industry and has shown greatly increased component life before failure. This or something similar should be a standard treatment for everything metal that is intended for long term use in space.

Love your elegant (Payday candy bar) model. On Earth this can also be a problem. I made a mechanical painting easel for the quadrupedic artist Patrick Hogan. The driver block on the (up/down) motorized Acme screw (jack screw) kept sticking. I wire brushed and lubed it over and over again but it just kept seizing, and never in the same place. Rotating the nut by hand it never stuck.
Pat got me phone call with Peter Carlson (the guy who later fabricated Jeff Koon's Balloon Dogs and other large sculptures). Peter zeroed right in on the problem. Steel drive nut and steel Acme screw -spontaneous welding. "Use dissimilar metals". He couldn't explain exactly why it was happening but he was confident the solution would work. So I replaced the steel drive nut with a bronze one - never had another problem. I've seen it a few times since, usually it's steel and the surfaces are very flat but it's never been as much of a problem. I also suspect that it may also be a factor when a bolt freezes stuck.

Engineers routinely use guage blocks.  These are small blocks of steel that have been ground and polished so that their dimensions are optically perfect.  These come in many sizes and are stacked to give any size required.  Stacking them consists of "wringing" them together, which ensures the air between them is excluded.  Once this is done, the multiple blocks will hold together as if they are one piece.  If, however, the engineer forgets to separate them and leaves them together overnight, they fuse together for good.  This is a well known issue known by any precision metalworking engineer.  It seems if you remove all other material (including the atmosphere) from between two pieces of identical metal, the two become one.

You don't have to get materials above the melting point to make them fuse together. One can get materials fuse together through a process could sintering. Sintering is where one allows two materials to diffuse into each other. It may take seconds to hours dependent on the materials and temperatures. One example of diffusion, is coating one side of clean bare silicon wafer with gold. One can wait a few hours and detect that the gold has diffused to the other side of the silicon wafer. This technique is used in manufacturing where joining materials is needed. One example is in the production of microwave tubes.

Cold welding was known before Gemini 4. As for the gold to gold welding, in 1983 IBM reported at a Vacuum Society meeting that the could weld macro-gold-wires together at room temperature in air with a bit of pressure at room temperature. They just had to get the surfaces atomically clean. They did that by using ultra-violent light and spraying pure clean oxygen on the surfaces just before bonding. For the space program though NASA had DuPont develop perfluorocarbon oils and greases. Some of those greases have a vapor pressure around 10E-14 Torr.


I think we need to be able to weld in space using robots so structures larger than what we can launch can be built. Cold welding will not suffice for this because of the cleanness and smoothness required. As for using plastics instead of metals, I guess it will be fine for short missions. But the Long Duration Space Environment Experiment on materials in the 1980s easily showed that plastics degraded more quickly than anticipated. This degradation was due to ultra-violent radiation breaking chemical bonds, atomic oxygen oxidizing the plastics and micro-meteorites ablating the plastics.

I hate seeing people weld without proper PPE... As a certified pipeline welder with years of experience, listen to me when I tell you folks to keep your skin covered while welding. The light emitted from the arc will burn the living crap out of your skin in a matter of minutes. There's plenty of studies showing the danger of skin cancer caused by this. Obviously at the beginning of this video, his short duration without gloves and in a T-shirt was only to showcase the art of tig welding. I'm sure he is just fine and it is his choice to do with his body as he pleases. But I am worried that people who have never been around welding may assume that it is ok to weld without gloves or with skin exposed while possibly only wearing a T-shirt. And as an informative video, I feel like the editors should try to keep these things in mind before posting a video.

That being said, I do enjoy your content, but this is a common mistake that many new welders don't take serious, and they should.

After a lot of thought, this is my conclusion on whats actually happening here. I've been a welder for many years and the explanation just doesn't add up to me. On the surface of Earth we are at an average of 1 atmosphere, in space there are 0 atmospheres obviously (Vacuum of space also makes no since, there are not negative atmospheres, its an environment without pressure. That's why pressurized environments are equalized to 0.) so why would that make a difference? I don't think it does. The ISS's average outside temp can reach plus or minus 250F which isn't sufficient enough to conjoin steel. However, with the lack of an atmosphere comes a lack of protection from solar and cosmic radiation which is very present in space. My two sense is telling me that after enough exposure to radiation (steel is a great conductor) the radiation is causing a reaction in the gaps between two steel surfaces, conjoining them. This bond isn't very strong considering one or two men in space suits managed to brake that bond in the hinges and shut the hatch. Picture this. ] [ <-- those two lines represent the two steel surfaces. They would be tightly fit but there is still a gap between them allowing for movement. Now radiation waves move a lot like sound waves, they would be bouncing and passing through the structure rapidly, but what happens when there is a small space between two surfaces and some radiation waves become "trapped" between. They would bounce off each surface at a rapid rate ]z[ causing heat in turn conjoining the two materials. Of course it wouldn't be hot to the astronauts, the would be very localized to those specific areas away from the handle and by the time the astronauts would be able to remove their suits (an atmosphere would have to be produced in the shuttle) the heat would be removed from the steel into the now atmosphere remaining virtually undetected. Just my thoughts. let me know what you guys think.

Actually cold welding can be well observed on the Earth on macroscale. Just put together two plates of silver or gold -- and clamp them together for multiple days. Bare metals are rare, and usually some form of coating is used.

Cold welding is not just a "space problem," it can happen with many metal-metal contacts anywhere (including "on Earth"), especially in vacuum or in threads, where high local stresses can occur, but not exclusively... Some metals are more prone to this than others, which can be related to building up (or not building up) a surface oxide, or how well (i.e. how smoothly) they can be machined, etc. The effect is sometimes also called "galling" in the context of screws "seizing". Three are other reasons for threads "seizing" but this is one... And so you are right, using dissimilar metals or alloys will help, or the use of a properly designed coating. (A lubricant film could be considered a coating for this purpose too...)
